expanded_description: Position-time graphs provide a powerful visual representation of motion, encoding information about position, displacement, velocity, and the character of motion in a single diagram. Learning to read and interpret these graphs is essential for analyzing motion.

core_concept.principle: A position-time graph plots position (vertical axis) versus time (horizontal axis). The shape and slope of the line reveal the motion: slope equals velocity, steeper slope means faster speed, upward slope means positive velocity, downward slope means negative velocity, horizontal line means at rest, and curved line means changing velocity (acceleration).
core_concept.explanation: Position-time graphs transform motion data into visual form, making patterns immediately apparent. Every point on the graph shows where an object is at a specific time. The slope at any point gives the velocity at that moment—this is the key relationship: $\text{slope} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = v$. Straight lines indicate constant velocity (uniform motion), while curves indicate changing velocity (acceleration). By analyzing the graph's shape, slope, and features, you can determine position at any time, calculate velocities, identify when objects meet, and understand the complete story of the motion. These graphs are fundamental tools in kinematics and appear throughout physics.

sections.introduction: Understanding the basic structure and components of position-time graphs is the first step in using them effectively.

key_concept.definition: A position-time graph has time ($t$) on the horizontal axis (independent variable) and position ($x$ or $y$) on the vertical axis (dependent variable). Each point $(t, x)$ represents the object's position at that specific time.
key_concept.context: The graph shows how position depends on time. Time always increases to the right; position can increase (upward), decrease (downward), or stay constant (horizontal).

principles.statement: Horizontal axis: time ($t$), typically in seconds. Vertical axis: position ($x$ or $y$), typically in meters. Both must be labeled with units.
principles.application: Always check axis labels to know what's being plotted and in what units.
principles.example: Horizontal: Time (s) from 0 to 10. Vertical: Position (m) from 0 to 50. Shows 10-second motion with positions from 0 to 50 m.

principles.statement: Each point gives position at a specific time. Read across from time axis, up to curve, then left to position axis.
principles.application: To find position at $t = 5$ s: find 5 on horizontal axis, go up to the curve, read across to vertical axis.
principles.example: Point at $(3 \text{ s}, 20 \text{ m})$ means: at time $t = 3$ s, object is at position $x = 20$ m.

principles.statement: Vertical intercept (where line crosses position axis at $t = 0$) gives initial position $x_i$. Horizontal intercept (where line crosses time axis at $x = 0$) gives when object passes origin.
principles.application: Initial position read from vertical intercept.
principles.example: Line crosses position axis at 10 m: object starts at $x_i = 10$ m. Line crosses time axis at $t = 2$ s: object reaches origin at 2 seconds.

principles.statement: The slope of a position-time graph at any point equals the velocity at that moment: $\text{slope} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = v$
principles.application: Calculate slope to find velocity. Steeper slope = faster speed.
principles.example: Slope = $\frac{30 \text{ m} - 10 \text{ m}}{6 \text{ s} - 2 \text{ s}} = \frac{20 \text{ m}}{4 \text{ s}} = 5$ m/s. Velocity is +5 m/s.

characteristics: Position where curve is located tells where object is

examples.explanation: Constant slope → constant velocity → uniform motion. Object moving at steady rate.
Changing slope → changing velocity → acceleration present. Object speeding up or slowing down.
Zero slope → zero velocity → object at rest. Position not changing.
Steep slope → large velocity (fast). Gentle slope → small velocity (slow). Steepness = speed.
Positive slope → positive velocity → moving in positive direction.
Negative slope → negative velocity → moving in negative direction.

worked_examples.title: Reading a Position-Time Graph
worked_examples.problem: A position-time graph shows a straight line passing through $(0 \text{ s}, 5 \text{ m})$ and $(8 \text{ s}, 45 \text{ m})$. Find: (a) initial position, (b) position at $t = 6$ s, (c) velocity.

step_by_step.explanation: Read vertical intercept (position at $t = 0$)
Straight line, so use linear equation. First find slope (velocity): $v = \frac{45 - 5}{8 - 0} = \frac{40}{8} = 5$ m/s
Equation: $x = x_i + vt = 5 + 5t$. At $t = 6$ s: $x = 5 + 5(6) = 35$ m
step_by_step.calculation: Or read directly from graph at $t = 6$ s: $x = 35$ m

step_by_step.explanation: Already calculated: slope = velocity

worked_examples.concept_applied: Read initial position from intercept. Calculate velocity from slope. Use equation or graph to find position at any time.

image.alt: Labeled position-time graph showing axes, intercepts, and sample point
image.caption: Graph anatomy: time on horizontal axis, position on vertical axis, slope = velocity

sections.introduction: The most important skill in reading position-time graphs is calculating velocity from the slope of the line or curve.

key_concept.definition: Velocity equals the slope of the position-time graph: $v = \text{slope} = \frac{\text{rise}}{\text{run}} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{x_2 - x_1}{t_2 - t_1}$. For straight lines, slope is constant. For curves, slope varies—find instantaneous slope at a point.
key_concept.context: This slope-velocity relationship is fundamental. Every feature of motion connects to slope: constant slope = constant velocity, changing slope = acceleration, zero slope = at rest, positive slope = positive velocity, negative slope = negative velocity.

principles.statement: Choose two points on the line: $(t_1, x_1)$ and $(t_2, x_2)$. Calculate: $\text{slope} = \frac{x_2 - x_1}{t_2 - t_1}$
principles.application: Use any two points on a straight line—slope is the same everywhere. For curves, use points very close together for instantaneous slope.
principles.example: Points: $(2 \text{ s}, 10 \text{ m})$ and $(5 \text{ s}, 25 \text{ m})$. Slope $= \frac{25 - 10}{5 - 2} = \frac{15}{3} = 5$ m/s.

principles.principle: Sign of Slope = Direction of Velocity
principles.statement: Positive slope → positive velocity (moving in + direction). Negative slope → negative velocity (moving in - direction). Zero slope → zero velocity (at rest).
principles.application: Slope direction immediately tells motion direction.
principles.example: Upward-sloping line: slope > 0, so $v > 0$ (moving in positive direction). Downward-sloping: slope < 0, so $v < 0$ (moving in negative direction).

principles.statement: Steeper slope (larger |slope|) = faster speed. Gentler slope (smaller |slope|) = slower speed.
principles.example: Line A: slope = 10 m/s. Line B: slope = 3 m/s. Object A is faster (10 m/s > 3 m/s).

principles.statement: Slope has units of (position units)/(time units) = velocity units. Typically m/s.
principles.application: Always include units in velocity calculation.

worked_examples.title: Calculating Velocity from Straight Line
worked_examples.problem: A position-time graph is a straight line through $(1 \text{ s}, 12 \text{ m})$ and $(7 \text{ s}, 48 \text{ m})$. Find the velocity.

step_by_step.explanation: Positive slope → positive velocity. Object moving in positive direction at 6 m/s.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Velocity = slope of position-time graph. Use any two points on the line.

worked_examples.title: Negative Velocity from Downward Slope
worked_examples.problem: A graph shows a straight line from $(0 \text{ s}, 80 \text{ m})$ to $(10 \text{ s}, 30 \text{ m})$. Find velocity.

step_by_step.explanation: $\text{slope} = \frac{30 - 80}{10 - 0} = \frac{-50 \text{ m}}{10 \text{ s}}$
Negative slope → negative velocity. Position decreasing → moving in negative direction at 5 m/s.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Downward-sloping line has negative slope, indicating negative velocity.

worked_examples.title: Zero Velocity from Horizontal Line
worked_examples.problem: Between $t = 3$ s and $t = 7$ s, the graph is a horizontal line at $x = 25$ m. What is the velocity during this interval?

step_by_step.explanation: Horizontal means position not changing. $\Delta x = 0$.
$\text{slope} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{25 - 25}{7 - 3} = \frac{0}{4}$
Zero slope → zero velocity → object at rest (stationary at position 25 m).

worked_examples.concept_applied: Horizontal line (slope = 0) means object is stationary.

worked_examples.title: Comparing Velocities from Multiple Lines
worked_examples.problem: On the same graph: Line A has slope +8 m/s, Line B has slope -6 m/s, Line C has slope +3 m/s. (a) Which object is fastest? (b) Which object moves in negative direction?

step_by_step.explanation: Speed = |velocity| = |slope|. A: |8| = 8 m/s. B: |-6| = 6 m/s. C: |3| = 3 m/s.
Negative slope → negative velocity. Line B has slope -6 m/s < 0.
step_by_step.calculation: Object B moves in negative direction

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Object A is fastest (8 m/s), (b) Object B moves in negative direction
worked_examples.concept_applied: Compare |slope| to compare speeds. Negative slope means negative velocity (negative direction).

image.alt: Diagram showing how to calculate slope using rise over run
image.caption: Velocity = slope = rise/run = Δx/Δt. Choose any two points on the line.

sections.introduction: The shape of a position-time graph reveals the type of motion occurring. Recognizing these patterns allows instant identification of motion characteristics.

key_concept.definition: Straight lines indicate uniform motion (constant velocity). Curves indicate accelerated motion (changing velocity). Horizontal lines indicate rest (zero velocity). The specific shape and direction provide detailed information about how the object moves.
key_concept.context: By learning to recognize standard graph shapes, you can immediately identify motion type, determine if an object is speeding up or slowing down, and predict future behavior.

examples.explanation: Positive constant velocity. Moving steadily in positive direction. Example: car on cruise control going forward.
Negative constant velocity. Moving steadily in negative direction. Example: elevator descending at constant speed.
Zero velocity. Object at rest. Example: book sitting on table.

classifications.value: Increasing velocity (in positive or negative direction)

examples.explanation: Positive velocity increasing. Speeding up in positive direction. Example: car accelerating forward from rest.
Negative velocity increasing (becoming more negative). Speeding up in negative direction. Example: object in free fall (downward = negative).
Positive velocity decreasing. Slowing down. Example: car braking (still moving forward but slowing).
Velocity decreases to zero, then reverses. Example: ball thrown upward (slows, stops at peak, falls back down). Graph shows upward curve that peaks and comes back down.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Motion Type from Graph Shape
worked_examples.problem: Describe the motion for each graph segment: (a) Straight line sloping upward, (b) Horizontal line, (c) Curve that gets steeper upward, (d) Straight line sloping downward.

step_by_step.explanation: Constant positive slope → constant positive velocity → uniform motion in positive direction
Zero slope → zero velocity → object at rest (stationary)
Slope increasing → velocity increasing → speeding up in positive direction (positive acceleration)
Constant negative slope → constant negative velocity → uniform motion in negative direction

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Uniform motion, positive direction, (b) At rest, (c) Accelerating, speeding up in positive direction, (d) Uniform motion, negative direction
worked_examples.concept_applied: Graph shape reveals motion type: straight = uniform, horizontal = rest, curve = accelerated.

worked_examples.title: Ball Thrown Upward Graph
worked_examples.problem: A ball is thrown upward (positive direction). Sketch and describe its position-time graph from release until it returns to starting height.

step_by_step.explanation: Positive velocity (upward) but decreasing (gravity slowing it). Curve slopes upward but is flattening (concave down). Slope starts steep, gets less steep.
Velocity = 0 momentarily. Slope = 0. Graph has horizontal tangent at highest point.
Negative velocity (downward) increasing in magnitude. Curve slopes downward getting steeper (concave up in negative direction). Position decreasing, slope getting more negative.
Parabola opening downward. Starts at origin, curves up to peak, curves back down to origin (if caught at same height).

worked_examples.final_answer: Parabolic curve: rises with decreasing slope (slowing down going up), reaches peak (v=0), falls with increasing negative slope (speeding up going down). Concave down throughout (constant downward acceleration from gravity).
worked_examples.concept_applied: Constant acceleration produces parabolic position-time curve. Shape reflects velocity changes.

image.alt: Collection of position-time graphs showing different motion types
image.caption: Graph shapes: straight line = uniform motion, curve up = speeding up, curve flattening = slowing down, horizontal = at rest

sections.introduction: Plotting multiple objects on one graph allows comparison of motions and finding when/where objects meet.

key_concept.definition: When multiple position-time lines appear on one graph, each line represents a different object. Points where lines intersect indicate same position at same time (objects meet). Relative slopes show relative velocities.
key_concept.context: Comparing graphs visually reveals relationships between objects: which is faster, which starts ahead, when they meet, when one overtakes the other.

principles.statement: Where two lines cross, both objects are at the same position at the same time—they meet.
principles.application: Find intersection to determine when/where objects meet.
principles.example: Line A and Line B cross at $(5 \text{ s}, 30 \text{ m})$. Both objects are at position 30 m at time 5 s—they meet there.

principles.statement: Steeper slope = faster object. Compare steepness to see which object moves faster.
principles.application: Visual comparison of speeds without calculation.
principles.example: Line A steeper than Line B → Object A is faster than Object B.

principles.statement: Vertical distance between lines at a given time shows how far apart the objects are at that moment.
principles.application: Measure vertical gap to find separation distance.
principles.example: At $t = 4$ s: Line A at $x = 25$ m, Line B at $x = 15$ m. Separation = 25 - 15 = 10 m apart.

principles.statement: Vertical intercepts show where each object starts ($t = 0$).
principles.example: Line A intercepts at 10 m, Line B at 0 m. A starts 10 m ahead of B.

worked_examples.title: Finding Meeting Point
worked_examples.problem: Object A: $x_A = 0 + 8t$ (starts at origin, velocity +8 m/s). Object B: $x_B = 60 - 4t$ (starts at 60 m, velocity -4 m/s). (a) Sketch both on one graph. (b) When and where do they meet?

step_by_step.explanation: Line A: starts at $(0, 0)$, slopes upward with slope +8 m/s. Line B: starts at $(0, 60)$, slopes downward with slope -4 m/s. Lines will intersect.
Set equations equal: $8t = 60 - 4t$
Use either equation: $x_A = 8(5) = 40$ m. Check: $x_B = 60 - 4(5) = 60 - 20 = 40$ m ✓

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Two intersecting straight lines (one upward, one downward). (b) Meet at $t = 5$ s, position $x = 40$ m
worked_examples.concept_applied: Intersection of position-time lines shows when/where objects meet. Set equations equal to find intersection.

worked_examples.title: Comparing Three Objects
worked_examples.problem: Three objects plotted on same graph: Object 1: horizontal line at $x = 20$ m. Object 2: straight line, slope +5 m/s, starts at origin. Object 3: straight line, slope +3 m/s, starts at $x = 10$ m. (a) Which is fastest? (b) Which starts ahead? (c) Do any meet?

step_by_step.explanation: Object 1: slope = 0 (at rest). Object 2: slope = +5 m/s. Object 3: slope = +3 m/s. Fastest is Object 2 (largest |slope|).
At $t = 0$: Object 1 at 20 m, Object 2 at 0 m, Object 3 at 10 m. Object 1 starts farthest ahead.
Object 2: $x = 5t$ will eventually reach Object 1's position: $5t = 20$ → $t = 4$ s. Objects 2 and 1 meet at $t = 4$ s, $x = 20$ m.
Object 3: $x = 10 + 3t$ will reach 20 m: $10 + 3t = 20$ → $3t = 10$ → $t = 3.33$ s. Objects 3 and 1 meet.

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Object 2 is fastest (5 m/s), (b) Object 1 starts ahead (at 20 m), (c) Object 2 meets Object 1 at t=4s, Object 3 meets Object 1 at t=3.33s
worked_examples.concept_applied: Compare slopes for speeds, intercepts for starting positions, find intersections for meeting points.

worked_examples.title: Chase Problem
worked_examples.problem: Object A starts 50 m ahead with velocity +2 m/s. Object B starts at origin with velocity +6 m/s. (a) Does B catch A? (b) If so, when and where?

step_by_step.explanation: Object A: $x_A = 50 + 2t$. Object B: $x_B = 0 + 6t = 6t$
B is faster (6 m/s > 2 m/s), so B's line is steeper. B will eventually catch A. Yes, B catches A.
Set equal: $6t = 50 + 2t$ → $4t = 50$

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Yes, B catches A (B is faster), (b) At $t = 12.5$ s, position $x = 75$ m
worked_examples.concept_applied: Faster object (steeper slope) eventually catches slower object that starts ahead. Set equations equal to find when/where.

image.caption: Multiple objects: different lines for different objects, intersection = meeting point, slopes compare velocities

sections.section_title: Creating Position-Time Graphs from Motion Descriptions
sections.introduction: Being able to construct position-time graphs from written descriptions or data is essential for visualizing and analyzing motion.

key_concept.definition: To create a position-time graph: (1) identify initial position and velocity, (2) determine if motion is uniform (straight line) or accelerated (curve), (3) plot key points, (4) connect with appropriate line or curve, (5) check that slope matches velocity.
key_concept.context: Translating motion descriptions into graphs develops understanding of the relationship between motion characteristics and graph features.

process_flow.process: Read Problem and Identify Key Information
process_flow.description: Extract: initial position ($x_i$), velocity ($v$), acceleration ($a$), motion type.
process_flow.mechanism: Look for phrases: 'starts at,' 'constant velocity,' 'accelerating,' 'at rest.'
process_flow.result: Know what graph should look like.

process_flow.description: Draw and label axes: horizontal = time (s), vertical = position (m).
process_flow.mechanism: Choose scale that fits the motion range.
applications: If motion lasts 10 s, time axis 0 to 10 s
If positions range 0 to 50 m, position axis 0 to 50 m

process_flow.description: Mark starting point at $(0, x_i)$ or $(t_i, x_i)$ if not starting at $t=0$.
Uniform motion → straight line. Accelerated motion → curve.
process_flow.mechanism: Use velocity to determine slope. Draw line with appropriate shape.
applications: Constant $v = +8$ m/s → upward straight line from $(0, x_i)$ with slope 8
Speeding up → upward curve getting steeper

process_flow.description: Check: slope matches velocity, shape matches motion type. Add any specified points.
process_flow.mechanism: Calculate position at specific times and verify graph passes through those points.
applications: If $v = 5$ m/s and $x_i = 10$ m, at $t = 4$ s should be at $x = 10 + 5(4) = 30$ m. Verify graph passes through $(4, 30)$.

worked_examples.title: Graphing Uniform Motion
worked_examples.problem: Sketch a position-time graph for: Object starts at $x = 8$ m at $t = 0$, moves with constant velocity $v = +6$ m/s for 5 seconds.

step_by_step.explanation: $x_i = 8$ m, $v = +6$ m/s (constant), duration = 5 s
Constant velocity → straight line, positive slope
Draw axes. Plot $(0, 8)$ and $(5, 38)$. Connect with straight line. Line should slope upward (positive velocity).
Slope $= \frac{38 - 8}{5 - 0} = \frac{30}{5} = 6$ m/s ✓ Matches given velocity

worked_examples.final_answer: Straight line from $(0, 8)$ to $(5, 38)$, sloping upward with slope +6 m/s
worked_examples.concept_applied: Constant velocity produces straight line. Slope equals velocity. Start at initial position.

worked_examples.title: Graphing Object at Rest
worked_examples.problem: Sketch position-time graph for object at rest at position $x = 15$ m from $t = 0$ to $t = 8$ s.

step_by_step.explanation: At rest → $v = 0$, position constant at $x = 15$ m
Zero velocity → horizontal line (zero slope)
Draw horizontal line at $x = 15$ m from $t = 0$ to $t = 8$ s

worked_examples.final_answer: Horizontal line at $x = 15$ m for entire time interval
worked_examples.concept_applied: Object at rest → horizontal line (position doesn't change, slope = 0).

worked_examples.title: Graphing Multi-Segment Motion
worked_examples.problem: Sketch graph for: (1) Start at origin, velocity $+4$ m/s for 5 s, (2) Then at rest for 3 s, (3) Then velocity $-3$ m/s for 4 s.

step_by_step.explanation: Start at $(0, 0)$. $v = +4$ m/s for 5 s. End: $x = 0 + 4(5) = 20$ m. Draw upward straight line from $(0, 0)$ to $(5, 20)$.
At rest for 3 s at position $x = 20$ m. Draw horizontal line from $(5, 20)$ to $(8, 20)$.
Start at 20 m. $v = -3$ m/s for 4 s. End: $x = 20 + (-3)(4) = 20 - 12 = 8$ m. Draw downward straight line from $(8, 20)$ to $(12, 8)$.
Three connected segments: upward slope, horizontal, downward slope. Continuous (no breaks).

worked_examples.final_answer: Three-segment graph: upward line (0-5s), horizontal line (5-8s), downward line (8-12s), ending at $(12, 8)$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Multi-segment motion: connect segments continuously. Each segment's slope matches its velocity.

image.caption: Creating graphs: identify initial position, use velocity for slope, draw appropriate line type

sections.section_title: Common Mistakes and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Certain errors appear frequently when working with position-time graphs. Recognizing and avoiding these mistakes improves accuracy.

categories.description: Thinking the graph shows distance traveled instead of position.

examples.explanation: Seeing negative position and thinking it's impossible because 'distance can't be negative.'
Position can be negative (means object is on negative side of origin). Distance is different from position. Graph shows position, not distance.
$x = -10$ m means object is 10 m in the negative direction (e.g., 10 m to the left), NOT that distance is negative.

categories.description: Believing steeper line means object traveled farther.

examples.explanation: Confusing steepness (velocity) with height (position).
Steeper slope means faster (higher velocity), not necessarily farther. How far depends on velocity AND time.
Object A: slow (gentle slope) for long time might travel farther than Object B: fast (steep slope) for short time.

categories.description: Thinking curved graph means curved path.

examples.explanation: Seeing parabolic position-time graph and thinking object moved in parabolic path.
Position-time graph does NOT show the path taken. It shows how position changes with time. Object can move in straight line and still produce curved graph (if accelerating).
Ball dropped straight down: straight path, but parabolic position-time graph (due to constant acceleration).
Slope = 5 (missing units)
Slope has units of position/time. Slope = 5 m/s (with units)

categories.description: Putting position on horizontal axis instead of vertical.

examples.explanation: Drawing with position horizontal and time vertical (backwards)
Convention: time always on horizontal axis (independent variable), position on vertical axis (dependent variable). Position depends on time.

summary: Position-time graphs plot position (vertical axis) versus time (horizontal axis), with each point showing where an object is at a specific time. The fundamental relationship: slope of the position-time graph equals velocity ($\text{slope} = \Delta x / \Delta t = v$). Graph interpretation: straight line indicates constant velocity (uniform motion), curved line indicates changing velocity (acceleration), horizontal line indicates zero velocity (object at rest), upward slope indicates positive velocity (moving in positive direction), downward slope indicates negative velocity (moving in negative direction), steeper slope indicates faster speed. For straight lines, slope is constant everywhere; calculate using any two points: $\text{slope} = (x_2 - x_1)/(t_2 - t_1)$. For curves, slope varies—steepening curve means increasing speed, flattening curve means decreasing speed. Concave up (∪) indicates speeding up; concave down (∩) indicates slowing down. The vertical intercept gives initial position ($x_i$); horizontal intercept shows when object passes through origin. When multiple objects appear on same graph, intersection points show when/where objects meet, relative slopes show relative velocities, vertical separation shows distance between objects. To create position-time graphs: identify initial position and velocity, determine if motion is uniform (straight) or accelerated (curved), plot key points, connect with appropriate line, verify slope matches velocity. Common mistakes to avoid: confusing position with distance (position can be negative), thinking steeper means farther (steeper means faster, not necessarily farther traveled), interpreting graph curve as object's path (graph shows position vs time, not physical trajectory), forgetting units in slope calculation, placing axes incorrectly. Position-time graphs are fundamental tools for visualizing motion, analyzing velocity changes, predicting future positions, and comparing different motions.
